tasks: Create a simple wireframe of a login form using the 8-point grid system, focusing on proper alignment and spacing (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/8-point-grid-system).

Write down 5 common UX principles that you've learned so far, but don't fully understand. Research each principle and create a brief summary of its meaning and application (Reference: https://nngroup.com/articles/ten-usability-heuristics/).
Sketch out 3 different error states for a login form, focusing on clear and concise messaging. Use Occam's Razor to simplify the design.

Create a low-fidelity prototype of a navigation menu using paper sketches or digital tools like Figma or Sketch. Focus on usability and simplicity (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/8-point-grid-system).
Conduct 1 user interview and document 3 pain points related to the navigation menu using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework. Take notes on the user's thoughts and feelings about the current design.
Design a new color palette for your portfolio's navigation, focusing on contrast and visual hierarchy (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/aesthetic-usability-effect/).

Create a high-fidelity prototype of the navigation menu using digital tools like Figma or Sketch. Focus on usability, simplicity, and visual appeal (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/8-point-grid-system).
Conduct 1 user testing session with your navigation menu prototype and document 5 new pain points or insights gained from the feedback.
Design a new typography system for your portfolio's navigation, focusing on legibility and consistency (Reference: https://nngroup.com/articles/ten-usability-heuristics/).
Create a comprehensive design system document for your portfolio's navigation, including all the elements you've designed so far. Use Occam's Razor to simplify and streamline the content.
Conduct 2 user interviews and document 10 pain points or insights gained from the feedback on your navigation menu design using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework.
Design a new icon set for your portfolio's navigation, focusing on simplicity and visual appeal (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/aesthetic-usability-effect/).

resources.readup: As an Explorer UX designer, your role is to uncover new ideas and possibilities by immersing yourself in user research, testing assumptions, and crafting intuitive designs that spark curiosity and drive exploration. By leveraging your strengths in product thinking, collaboration, and communication, you have the power to shape the future of products and experiences that delight users.

resources.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
resources.description: 7 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design ================================================= Jakob Nielsen ![](https://media.nngroup.com/medi...

topics.name: Applying Occam's Razor for Simplified UI Design
topics.summary: Mastering Occam's Razor will help you eliminate unnecessary complexity in your designs, resulting in a more intuitive user experience.
practice_points: Analyze 3 existing products and identify areas where Occam's Razor can be applied to simplify their UI design. Document findings and propose simplified solutions.
Create a case study of a successful product that effectively uses Occam's Razor to reduce cognitive load. Explain the design decisions and their impact on user experience.

topics.name: Conducting User Interviews with the Jobs-to-be-Done Framework
topics.summary: Using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework will help you uncover users' underlying motivations and behaviors, leading to more effective design solutions.
practice_points: Conduct 2 user interviews using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework and document findings. Analyze the results to identify patterns and insights that can inform your design decisions.
Create a user persona based on your research findings. Ensure the persona accurately represents the target audience's needs, motivations, and behaviors.

topics.name: Applying Jakob’s Law for Effective Navigation
topics.summary: Mastering Jakob’s Law will help you create intuitive navigation that minimizes cognitive load and maximizes user engagement.
practice_points: Analyze 3 existing websites or applications that effectively use Jakob’s Law for navigation. Document the design decisions and explain how they contribute to a seamless user experience.

Design and test 2 different navigation prototypes using Jakob’s Law as a guiding principle. Analyze the results to identify areas for improvement and optimize the navigation for better user engagement.

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating a need to improve fundamental understanding of UX principles.
insights.detailed: The low score in UX Fundamentals suggests that the designer may not fully comprehend essential UX concepts such as user-centered design, wireframing, and usability testing. This lack of foundation can lead to subpar designs and poor user experiences.
actionable: Join online UX communities for feedback

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating a need to enhance visual design skills and knowledge.
insights.detailed: The low score in UI Craft & Visual Design implies that the designer may not possess sufficient expertise in visual design principles, color theory, typography, and layout. This can result in unappealing or inconsistent designs that fail to engage users.
actionable: Enroll in a UI design course
Study design systems and human-centered design
Experiment with different design tools and software

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating a need to improve research skills and validation processes.
insights.detailed: The moderate score in User Research & Validation suggests that the designer has some knowledge of user research methods but may not fully understand how to apply them effectively. This can lead to designs that don't accurately represent user needs or behaviors.
actionable: Conduct user interviews and usability testing
Learn about A/B testing and experimentation
Join online communities for user research best practices

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating a need to enhance product understanding and strategic thinking.
insights.detailed: The moderate-high score in Product Thinking & Strategy indicates that the designer has some knowledge of product development processes but may not fully grasp how to integrate user needs into product strategies. This can result in products that don't meet user expectations or are overly complex.
actionable: Join online communities for product thinking discussions

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating a need to improve collaboration and communication skills.
insights.detailed: The high score in Collaboration & Communication suggests that the designer is skilled at working with others and communicating effectively. However, this skillset may not be directly applicable to product development or design decisions.
actionable: Learn about conflict resolution and negotiation techniques
Join a design team or collaborate on projects
